title: Question 72

children: A 46-year-old man reports a 3-day history of a pruritic red rash that appeared 1 day after using a cologne he rediscovered in a bathroom drawer. The rash seems to be getting worse. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable.
Physical examination reveals poorly defined, eczematous-appearing patches with a few fine vesicles on the cheeks and anterior neck.
Which of the following is the most appropriate topical treatment?

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV, T-cell–mediated, delayed hypersensitivity reaction; sensitized T-cells trigger an inflammatory cascade, leading to an eczematous eruption at the site of contact.
To minimize the risk of complications, lower-potency topical glucocorticoids should be used in intertriginous areas, and hydrocortisone base should be used on the face.
Because this patient's rash involves the face and neck, the lowest-potency glucocorticoid, hydrocortisone (

), is the safest choice. This patient likely has allergic contact dermatitis in reaction to his cologne. Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV, T-cell–mediated, delayed hypersensitivity reaction. On re-exposure to a specific allergen, sensitized T-cells trigger an inflammatory cascade, leading to an eczematous eruption at the site of contact; rarely, a widespread eruption (autoeczematization or id reaction) may occur. Irritant contact dermatitis is more common than allergic contact dermatitis and is not immune mediated. Irritant contact dermatitis occurs from direct damage to the skin from harsh chemicals, soaps, or detergents. In addition to avoidance of the causative agent and treatment with emollients several times a day, topical glucocorticoids may help with symptom resolution. Appropriate choice of a topical glucocorticoid requires consideration of both the nature of the skin disease and the anatomic site being treated. Adverse effects of topical glucocorticoids include thinning of the skin, development of striae and hypopigmentation, and, with long-term use, development of telangiectasias. Anatomic areas that are at particular risk of complications from topical glucocorticoids include the face (particularly around the eyes, where skin is very thin) and any occluded areas of skin, such as the axillae, inguinal folds, skin under pendulous breasts, and abdominal pannus. When used on the face, halogenated (mid- and high-potency) glucocorticoids can induce acne, rosacea, perioral dermatitis, and rebound dermatitis. To minimize the risk of complications, lower-potency glucocorticoids should be used in intertriginous areas, and hydrocortisone base should be used on the face. Patients should be taught to use an adequate amount of glucocorticoid to treat the affected skin and should be encouraged to use it only as long as necessary.

The characteristic clinical presentation of tinea corporis, cruris, and faciei is annular scaly patches with central clearing and varying degrees of inflammation. Dermatophytosis of non-hair–bearing skin with limited involvement can be treated topically with imidazole creams, such as miconazole (
), clotrimazole, and ketoconazole. This patient does not have tinea, and miconazole is not indicated.

Pityriasis versicolor is one of the most common, chronic, superficial fungal infections and is typically found in young adults. It presents as asymptomatic, oval-to-round, minimally scaly, hyperpigmented or hypopigmented macules that can coalesce into patches on the trunk and upper extremities. Topical treatment using ketoconazole 2% shampoo or selenium sulfide suspension (

) is effective. Either treatment should be applied from the upper neck to the thighs and used to wash the scalp. This patient does not have pityriasis versicolor and treatment with selenium sulfide is not necessary.
